Filter predicates

Damiano Oldoni

2021-05-25

Source: vignettes/filter-predicates.Rmd
filter-predicates.Rmd

This vignette shows what filter predicates are and how to use them in get_*() functions or in map_dep().

Setup

Load packages:

library(camtrapdp)
library(lubridate)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'lubridate'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     date, intersect, setdiff, union
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

By loading pacakge camtrapdp, a camera trap data package called camtrapdp is made available. This data package contains camera trap data of musk rats and coypus. We will use this variable from now on.

Filter predicates

All filter predicates are functions starting with pred prefix. They can be distinguished in four categories based on the type of inputs they accept:

  1. one argument, one value
  2. one argument, no value
  3. one argument, multiple values (vector)
  4. multiple predicates

They are called filter predicates because they build (dplyr) filter statement. Filter predicates return objects of class filter_predicate, which are a particular kind of list with the following slots:

  1. arg, the argument
  2. value, the value
  3. type, the type of filter predicate
  4. expr, the filter dplyr expression

One argument - one value predicates

This filter predicates accept one argument and one value.

pred(), pred_not()

The pred() is the most basic predicates and refers to equality statements. Example, if you want to select rows where column a is equal to 5:

pred(arg = "a", value = 5)
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "equals"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (a == 5)
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

The opposite operator of pred() (equals) is pred_not (notEquals):

pred_not(arg = "a", value = 5)
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "notEquals"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (a != 5)
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

pred_gt(), pred_gte(), pred_lt(), pred_lte()

These predicates express > (greaterThan), >= (greaterThanOrEqual),< (lessThan) and <= (lessThanOrEqual) respectively. Example: if you want to select rows where column a is greater than 5:

pred_gt(arg = "a", value = 5)
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "greaterThan"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (a > 5)
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

One argument - no value predicates

The predicate pred_na() compares the argument against NA. To select rows where column a is NA:

pred_na(arg = "a")
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "na"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (is.na(a))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

To select all the rows where a is not NA, you can use the opposite predicate pred_notna():

pred_notna(arg = "a")
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "notNa"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (!is.na(a))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

One argument - multiple value predicates

These predicates accept a vector with multiple values as argument. To get rows where column a is one of the values c(1,3,5):

pred_in(arg = "a", value = c(1,3,5))
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 1 3 5
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "in"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (a %in% c(1,3,5))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

The opposite of pred_in() is pred_notin():

pred_notin(arg = "a", value = c(1,3,5))
#> $arg
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $value
#> [1] 1 3 5
#> 
#> $type
#> [1] "notIn"
#> 
#> $expr
#> (!(a %in% c(1,3,5)))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

multiple predicates: pred_and() and pred_or()

You can combine the predicates described above to make more complex filter statements by using pred_and() (AND operator) and pred_or() (OR operator).

Some examples. Select rows where column a is equal to 5 and column b is not NA:

pred_and(pred("a", 5), pred_notna("b"))
#> $arg
#> $arg[[1]]
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $arg[[2]]
#> [1] "b"
#> 
#> 
#> $value
#> $value[[1]]
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> $value[[2]]
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> 
#> $type
#> $type[[1]]
#> [1] "equals"
#> 
#> $type[[2]]
#> [1] "notNa"
#> 
#> 
#> $expr
#> ((a == 5) & (!is.na(b)))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

Select rows where column a is equal to 5 or column b is not NA:

pred_or(pred("a", 5), pred_notna("b"))
#> $arg
#> $arg[[1]]
#> [1] "a"
#> 
#> $arg[[2]]
#> [1] "b"
#> 
#> 
#> $value
#> $value[[1]]
#> [1] 5
#> 
#> $value[[2]]
#> [1] NA
#> 
#> 
#> $type
#> $type[[1]]
#> [1] "equals"
#> 
#> $type[[2]]
#> [1] "notNa"
#> 
#> 
#> $expr
#> ((a == 5) | (!is.na(b)))
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "filter_predicate"

Notice how these two predicates return filter_predicate objects with the same structure as any other predicate, but with slots arg, value and type as long as the number of input predicates they combine.

How to use filter predicates

The filter predicates are useful to select a subset of deployments for the get_*() functions and the visualization function map_dep().

One predicate

Apply get_* functions only to the deployments with location name B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek or _ B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna:

get_n_obs(camtrapdp,
          pred_in("location_name",
                  c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek", "B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> df %>% filter((location_name %in% c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek","B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> # A tibble: 10 x 3
#>    deployment_id                        scientific_name         n
#>    <chr>                                <chr>               <int>
#>  1 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a Anas platyrhynchos      4
#>  2 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d Anas platyrhynchos      2
#>  3 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a Rattus norvegicus       0
#>  4 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d Rattus norvegicus       7
#>  5 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a Ondatra zibethicus      0
#>  6 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d Ondatra zibethicus      1
#>  7 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a Myocastor coypus        0
#>  8 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d Myocastor coypus        0
#>  9 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a Gallinula chloropus     0
#> 10 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d Gallinula chloropus     0
get_effort(camtrapdp,
           pred_in("location_name",
                   c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek", "B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> df %>% filter((location_name %in% c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek","B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   deployment_id                        effort               effort_unit
#>   <chr>                                <Duration>           <chr>      
#> 1 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a 274938s (~3.18 days) Duration   
#> 2 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d 356509s (~4.13 days) Duration
get_n_species(camtrapdp,
              pred_in("location_name",
                      c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek", "B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> df %>% filter((location_name %in% c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek","B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   deployment_id                            n
#>   <chr>                                <int>
#> 1 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a     1
#> 2 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d     3

Multiple predicates

As shown above, you can combine several predicates for more complex filtering. E.g. calculate the number of species detected by the deployments with one of the location names B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek and B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna, or deployments souther than 51.28 degrees:

get_n_species(camtrapdp,
              pred_or(
                pred_in("location_name",
                        c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek", "B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")),
                pred_lt("latitude", 51.28)))
#> df %>% filter(((location_name %in% c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek","B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")) | (latitude < 51.28)))
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>   deployment_id                            n
#>   <chr>                                <int>
#> 1 3b94f935-020f-49d8-bd59-1736f8a266c4     5
#> 2 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a     1
#> 3 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d     3

Same syntax is valid for visualizing such information via map_dep() function:

map_dep(camtrapdp,
        feature = "n_species", 
        pred_or(
          pred_in("location_name",
                  c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek", "B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")),
          pred_lt("latitude", 51.28)))
#> df %>% filter(((location_name %in% c("B_ML_val 06_Oostpolderkreek","B_ML_val 07_Sint-Anna")) | (latitude < 51.28)))

Notice also that you can pass as much predicates as you want to get_* functions or map_dep() by separating them with comma: they will be combined internally using the AND operator. E.g. to get effort of deployments southern than 51.28 degrees AND eastern than 3.59 degrees, you can simplify this:

get_n_species(camtrapdp,
              pred_and(pred_lt("latitude", 51.28),
                       pred_gt("longitude", 3.59)))
#> df %>% filter(((latitude < 51.28) & (longitude > 3.59)))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   deployment_id                            n
#>   <chr>                                <int>
#> 1 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a     1
#> 2 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d     3

by omitting the pred_and():

get_n_species(camtrapdp,
              pred_lt("latitude", 51.28),
              pred_gt("longitude", 3.59))
#> df %>% filter((latitude < 51.28) & (longitude > 3.59))
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   deployment_id                            n
#>   <chr>                                <int>
#> 1 9e84c750-e8fa-4502-ae12-cc6c75532f5a     1
#> 2 fff2f46e-8163-453c-9044-61fb77587f5d     3

This is similar to the behvaior of dplyr’s filter() function, where this:

camtrapdp$deployments %>%
  filter(latitude < 51.28 & longitude > 3.59)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 16
#>   deployment_id location_id location_name longitude latitude start              
#>   <chr>         <chr>       <chr>             <dbl>    <dbl> <dttm>             
#> 1 9e84c750-e8f… 56128022-6… B_ML_val 06_…      3.59     51.3 2020-06-03 20:04:33
#> 2 fff2f46e-816… 7c989f1e-4… B_ML_val 07_…      3.63     51.3 2020-06-03 21:12:52
#> # … with 10 more variables: end <dttm>, setup_by <chr>, camera_id <lgl>,
#> #   camera_model <lgl>, camera_interval <dbl>, camera_height <dbl>,
#> #   bait_use <lgl>, feature_type <lgl>, tags <chr>, comments <lgl>

is exactly the same as this:

camtrapdp$deployments %>%
  filter(latitude < 51.28, longitude > 3.59)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 16
#>   deployment_id location_id location_name longitude latitude start              
#>   <chr>         <chr>       <chr>             <dbl>    <dbl> <dttm>             
#> 1 9e84c750-e8f… 56128022-6… B_ML_val 06_…      3.59     51.3 2020-06-03 20:04:33
#> 2 fff2f46e-816… 7c989f1e-4… B_ML_val 07_…      3.63     51.3 2020-06-03 21:12:52
#> # … with 10 more variables: end <dttm>, setup_by <chr>, camera_id <lgl>,
#> #   camera_model <lgl>, camera_interval <dbl>, camera_height <dbl>,
#> #   bait_use <lgl>, feature_type <lgl>, tags <chr>, comments <lgl>

Happy filtering!
